puzzles.prompt:
Six artists — Aditi, Ben, Clara, Dev, Eva, and Farhan — are sitting around a circular table.

The following conditions apply:

• Aditi sits exactly two seats to the left of Ben (i.e., going clockwise from Aditi, there is exactly one person them).
• Clara sits directly opposite Dev.
• Eva is sitting immediately next to Aditi.
• Ben is not sitting next to Clara.
• Farhan sits two seats away from Eva (there is exactly one person between them).

Determine the complete seating arrangement in clockwise order, starting with Aditi.
puzzles.ai_solution_correct: Aditi, Dev, Ben, Farhan, Clara, Eva
puzzles.ai_solution_faulty: Aditi, Eva, Ben, Farhan, Clara, Dev
puzzles.ai_reasoning_correct: Fix Aditi at the top and list everyone clockwise. Aditi must be two seats to the left of Ben, so going clockwise we have Aditi → (someone) → Ben. Also, Eva is adjacent to Aditi, so Eva must be either immediately clockwise or counterclockwise. Try placing Eva immediately counterclockwise (… Eva, Aditi, …); then the person immediately clockwise of Aditi is Dev, giving Aditi → Dev → Ben and satisfying the two-seats-left rule. Clara must be directly opposite Dev in a 6-seat circle, so Clara is three seats away from Dev. That forces Farhan into the remaining seat, and we get the order Aditi, Dev, Ben, Farhan, Clara, Eva. Check: Aditi is two seats left of Ben (Aditi–Dev–Ben); Eva is next to Aditi; Farhan is two seats from Eva (Eva–Aditi–Dev–Ben–Farhan); Clara is opposite Dev; and Ben is not adjacent to Clara. All constraints are satisfied.
puzzles.ai_reasoning_faulty: Start with Aditi, and place Eva immediately to her right because they must be adjacent. Then, since Aditi must be two seats to the left of Ben, put Ben immediately after Eva, giving Aditi → Eva → Ben. Place Clara opposite Dev and Farhan into the remaining seat. This yields Aditi, Eva, Ben, Farhan, Clara, Dev.
puzzles.correct_solution: Aditi, Dev, Ben, Farhan, Clara, Eva
puzzles.explanation: By combining adjacency (Eva next to Aditi), distance constraints (Aditi two seats to the left of Ben; Farhan two seats from Eva), and the opposite condition (Clara opposite Dev), the only clockwise arrangement starting from Aditi that satisfies all conditions is Aditi, Dev, Ben, Farhan, Clara, Eva.
hints_correct: Start by fixing Aditi at a reference position on the circle to remove rotational symmetry.
Use the fact that Eva must sit immediately next to Aditi to narrow down two possible seats for Eva.
Aditi being exactly two seats to the left of Ben means there is exactly one person between them in clockwise order.
After placing Aditi, Eva, and Ben, use Clara opposite Dev and Farhan two seats away from Eva to fix the remaining positions.
hints_faulty: Fix Aditi first, and place Eva immediately clockwise from her so that the Aditi–Ben spacing can be aligned more cleanly.
After placing Eva next to Aditi, position Ben two seats further clockwise to satisfy the directional left-of relationship.
Once Aditi, Eva, and Ben are placed, you can anchor Clara opposite Dev and then assign Farhan to any remaining seat that avoids adjacency issues.
After Dev and Clara are positioned, fill the final seat by ensuring Farhan is not directly beside Eva.
awareness_Q: Q1. Without looking back, list the names of all six artists mentioned in the problem.
Q2. Do you recall any rule that fixes how far apart A and B must sit on the circle? Describe it in your own words.
Q3. What do you remember about E’s position relative to A? Is there any condition about them being adjacent or at a specific distance?
Q4. Is there any rule involving F and another specific person about how many seats apart they are? If yes, describe the relationship.
Q5. Do you remember any restriction on who can or cannot sit next to C? If yes, write it in your own words.

puzzles.prompt:
Five students — Aman, Bhavya, Chitra, Danish, and Esha — are standing in a line facing forward.

The following conditions apply:

• Aman stands somewhere ahead of Bhavya.
• Chitra is not at the front of the line.
• Esha is exactly in the middle position.
• Bhavya is not last.
• The person immediately behind Esha is Danish.

Determine the complete order from front (first) to back (last).
puzzles.ai_reasoning_correct: There are 5 positions; the middle is position 3. So Esha must be third. The person immediately behind Esha is fourth, so Danish must be in position 4. That leaves positions 1, 2, and 5 for Aman, Bhavya, and Chitra. Chitra cannot be in front, so Chitra cannot be in position 1 and must be in position 5. Bhavya is not last, so Bhavya cannot be in position 5 (already taken anyway) and must be either 1 or 2. Aman must stand ahead of Bhavya, so Aman must be in position 1 and Bhavya in position 2. The final order is Aman, Bhavya, Esha, Danish, Chitra.
puzzles.ai_reasoning_faulty: Since Esha is in the middle, she is in position 3 and Danish is immediately behind her in position 4. That leaves positions 1, 2, and 5 for Aman, Bhavya, and Chitra. Place Bhavya in front to satisfy the idea that she is important in the line, and put Aman behind her, giving Bhavya, Aman, Esha, Danish, and Chitra.
puzzles.explanation: Fixing Esha in the middle and Danish directly behind her forces the tail of the line. Chitra cannot be at the front, and Bhavya cannot be last, so Chitra ends up last. Aman must be ahead of Bhavya, which forces Aman to the front and Bhavya to second place, producing a unique valid ordering.
hints_correct: First fix Esha’s position using the information that she is in the middle of the line.
Use the clue about who stands immediately behind Esha to fix another position.
Consider which positions are left for Chitra, knowing she cannot stand at the very front.
Remember that Aman must be ahead of Bhavya, and Bhavya cannot be last.
hints_faulty: Esha is fixed in the middle of the line, with Danish directly behind her, so positions 3 and 4 are determined first.
Since Bhavya cannot be last, one of the available front positions can be assigned to her.
Aman only needs to appear somewhere ahead of Bhavya, so placing him immediately after her maintains their required order.
Chitra is not allowed at the front, so she can be placed in the remaining open position at the back of the line.
awareness_Q: Q1. Without looking back, list the names of all five students mentioned in the problem.
Q2. Do you remember any rule that fixes E's exact position in the line? If yes, describe which position it is.
Q3. What do you recall about the person who stands immediately behind E? Who is it, and how is that stated?
Q4. Is there any rule about whether B can be at the front or the back of the line? If yes, describe it in your own words.
Q5. What do you remember about the relative order between A and B (who must be ahead of whom)?

puzzles.prompt:
Five people — Riya, Kabir, Sanjay, Meera, and Tanvi — live in a five-floor building. The floors are numbered 1 (ground) to 5 (top). Exactly one person lives on each floor.

The following conditions apply:

• Sanjay lives two floors above Meera (i.e., there is one floor between Sanjay and Meera).
• Riya does not live on the 2nd floor.
• Tanvi lives immediately above Kabir.
• Meera is not on the ground floor (floor 1).
• Tanvi does not live on the top floor.

Determine which person lives on which floor from ground (1st) to top (5th).
puzzles.ai_reasoning_correct: Since Tanvi lives immediately above Kabir and cannot be on the top floor, the possible (Kabir, Tanvi) floor pairs are (1,2), (2,3), (3,4), or (4,5). Tanvi cannot be on floor 5, so (4,5) is invalid. Meera is not on floor 1. Sanjay lives two floors above Meera, so valid (Meera, Sanjay) pairs are (1,3), (2,4), or (3,5). But Meera cannot be on floor 1, so only (2,4) or (3,5) remain. Try (Meera, Sanjay) = (3,5). That leaves floors 1, 2, and 4 for Kabir, Tanvi, and Riya. To fit Tanvi immediately above Kabir without using floor 5, the only pair compatible with (3,5) is (1,2) for (Kabir, Tanvi). Then Riya must take the only remaining floor, floor 4, and she is not on floor 2, so all constraints are satisfied. The final assignment is: Kabir-1, Tanvi-2, Meera-3, Riya-4, Sanjay-5.
puzzles.ai_reasoning_faulty: Sanjay must live two floors above Meera, so if Meera is on floor 1, then Sanjay can be on floor 3. Tanvi lives immediately above Kabir, so choose Kabir on floor 2 and Tanvi on floor 3. Then Riya can take floor 4 and Sanjay floor 5.
puzzles.explanation: The pair constraints (Kabir–Tanvi consecutive; Meera–Sanjay with a gap of two floors) narrow down the possible combinations. Eliminating floors based on Meera not being on floor 1 and Tanvi not being on floor 5 leaves a single consistent arrangement: Kabir on 1, Tanvi on 2, Meera on 3, Riya on 4, and Sanjay on 5.
hints_correct: List all possible floor pairs for Kabir and Tanvi, given that Tanvi is immediately above Kabir.
List all possible floor pairs for Meera and Sanjay, given that Sanjay lives two floors above Meera.
Use the restrictions on Meera (not floor 1) and Tanvi (not floor 5) to eliminate impossible pairs.
Once two pairs are fixed, the remaining person must take the only remaining floor.
hints_faulty: Sanjay must be two floors above Meera, so placing Meera on a lower floor allows Sanjay to fit within the building.
Kabir and Tanvi occupy consecutive floors, so they can be assigned to the pair of floors immediately above Meera.
Riya can take one of the remaining upper floors, as her only restriction is avoiding floor 2.
Once Meera and Sanjay are positioned with the required spacing, the remaining three floors can be filled to respect adjacency or non-adjacency conditions.
awareness_Q: Q1. Without looking back, list the names of all five people living in the building.
Q2. Do you remember any rule that relates S' floor to M's floor (for example, how many floors apart they are)? Describe it.
Q3. What do you recall about T's position relative to Kabir (for example, whether she is immediately above or below)?
Q4. Is there any restriction on which floor M or T cannot live on (e.g., ground/top)? Note down whatever you remember.
Q5. Do you remember any floor number that R is specifically not allowed to occupy? If yes, write it in your own words.

puzzles.prompt:
Four professors — Prof. Arora, Prof. Banerjee, Prof. Chopra, and Prof. Deshmukh — must each be assigned exactly one of four courses: Math, Computer Science, Economics, or History. Each course is taught by exactly one professor.

The following constraints apply:

• Prof. Banerjee will not teach Economics or Math.
• Prof. Arora can teach only Math or Computer Science.
• Looking at their surnames in alphabetical order, the professor who teaches History comes later in this order than the professor who teaches Economics.
• Prof. Deshmukh refuses to teach Computer Science.

Determine which professor teaches which course. Arrange the answer in this order: Math, Computer Science, Economics, or History
puzzles.ai_solution_correct: Prof. Arora, Prof. Banerjee, Prof. Chopra, Prof. Deshmukh
puzzles.ai_solution_faulty: Prof. Deshmukh, Prof. Arora, Prof. Chopra, Prof. Banerjee
puzzles.ai_reasoning_correct: Prof. Banerjee will not teach Economics or Math, so Banerjee can only teach Computer Science or History. Prof. Arora can only teach Math or Computer Science. Prof. Deshmukh refuses Computer Science, so Deshmukh must teach either Economics or History. The History teacher must come later alphabetically than the Economics teacher. If Deshmukh taught Economics, then the History teacher would have to be someone alphabetically after Deshmukh, which is impossible because Deshmukh is last alphabetically. So Deshmukh must teach History. Then Economics must be taught by someone alphabetically before Deshmukh; the only remaining candidates are Arora, Banerjee, and Chopra. Banerjee cannot teach Economics, and Arora is restricted to Math or CS, so Economics must be taught by Chopra. That leaves Math and Computer Science for Arora and Banerjee. Banerjee cannot teach Math, so Banerjee must teach Computer Science and Arora must teach Math.
puzzles.ai_reasoning_faulty: Since Prof. Banerjee cannot teach Economics or Math, assign Banerjee to History. Then give Economics to Chopra and Computer Science to Arora, leaving Math for Deshmukh.
puzzles.correct_solution: Prof. Arora, Prof. Banerjee, Prof. Chopra, Prof. Deshmukh
puzzles.explanation: The key step is noticing that the alphabetical condition about History and Economics forces Deshmukh to be the History professor. From there, Economics must be assigned to Chopra, and Banerjee’s restrictions force her into Computer Science, leaving Math for Arora.
hints_correct: First, consider what Prof. Banerjee can and cannot teach.
Use the fact that Prof. Deshmukh cannot teach Computer Science to narrow down his options.
Pay close attention to the alphabetical condition relating the History teacher and the Economics teacher.
Once you fix who teaches History and Economics, the remaining two courses follow from Banerjee’s and Arora’s remaining options.
hints_faulty: Arora’s options are limited to Math or Computer Science, so one of those can be reserved early for her.
Deshmukh cannot teach Computer Science, so assigning him History will satisfy the alphabetical condition as well.
Identify the courses that Banerjee cannot take, leaving Computer Science and Economics.
Chopra has no restrictions and Arora can take either of the remaining options so any can be assigned to each other.
awareness_Q: Q1. Without looking back, list the names of all four professors.
Q2. Do you recall any restriction on which subjects Prof. B will not teach? Write down whatever you remember.
Q3. What do you remember about Prof. A's allowed subjects (which ones can A teach)?
Q4. Is there any rule that connects the surnames’ alphabetical order to which professor teaches History versus Economics? If yes, describe it in your own words.
Q5. Do you recall any subject that Prof. D refuses to teach? If yes, state it.

puzzles.prompt:
Five speakers — Gargi, Harsh, Isha, Jatin, and Kunal — are seated at a straight table facing the audience. The seats are arranged from left to right.

The following conditions apply:

• Gargi must sit at one of the two ends.
• Harsh cannot sit next to Isha.
• Jatin must sit immediately to the left of Kunal.
• Isha must be somewhere to the right of Gargi.
• Harsh cannot sit in an end seat.

Determine the complete left-to-right seating order.
puzzles.ai_reasoning_correct: Jatin must sit immediately to the left of Kunal, so they form a fixed pair (Jatin, Kunal) in adjacent seats. Gargi must sit at one of the ends, but Harsh cannot sit at an end. Also, Isha must be somewhere to the right of Gargi. If we place Gargi on the right end, Isha would have to be to her right, which is impossible, so Gargi must be on the left end. Harsh cannot be at an end, so Harsh must occupy some middle seat. The pair (Jatin, Kunal) must occupy two adjacent seats to the right of Harsh in such a way that Isha ends up to the right of Gargi. The only configuration that satisfies all conditions is Gargi in seat 1, Harsh in seat 2, Jatin in seat 3, Kunal in seat 4, and Isha in seat 5.
puzzles.ai_reasoning_faulty: Place Harsh at the leftmost end to get him out of the way, then put Gargi next to him, followed by the pair Jatin and Kunal, and finally Isha at the right end, giving Harsh, Gargi, Jatin, Kunal, Isha. This arrangement keeps Jatin immediately to the left of Kunal and places Isha to the right of Gargi.
puzzles.explanation: Gargi’s requirement to be at an end and Isha’s requirement to be to her right force Gargi to the leftmost seat. Harsh’s restriction against end seats keeps him in the interior. The (Jatin, Kunal) block must then fill the remaining two adjacent seats to the right of Harsh, leaving the last seat on the right for Isha.
hints_correct: First decide where Gargi can sit, given that she must be at an end and Isha must be to her right.
Use the restriction that Harsh cannot sit at an end to narrow down which middle seat he can occupy.
Remember that Jatin must be immediately to the left of Kunal; treat them as a two-person block.
Try placing the Jatin–Kunal block in different spots to see which position allows all constraints to be satisfied.
hints_faulty: Start by selecting an end seat for Gargi, and note that placing her on the right end keeps space available for Isha on her right.
With Gargi on the right end, the remaining seats open up naturally, and Harsh can be placed toward the left side of the arrangement while still avoiding adjacency conflicts.
Place the Jatin–Kunal block together in the central seats, keeping them between the two speakers already positioned at the ends.
Once the Jatin–Kunal block is set in the middle, the remaining open seat on the right naturally belongs to Isha, which completes the arrangement.
awareness_Q: Q1. Without looking back, list the names of all five speakers.
Q2. Do you recall any rule about where G must sit with respect to the ends of the table? Describe it briefly.
Q3. What do you remember about H's restrictions regarding which positions he can or cannot occupy (especially about end seats)?
Q4. Is there any rule about J's position relative to K (e.g., immediately to the left/right)? Write what you remember.
Q5. Do you remember any restriction on whether H and I can sit next to each other, or anything about I’s position relative to G? Describe whichever you recall.

puzzles.prompt:
Four meetings — HR, Sales, Tech, and Finance — must be scheduled in four consecutive one-hour slots: 9–10AM, 10–11AM, 11–12PM, and 12–1PM.

The following constraints apply:

• Finance cannot be scheduled before Sales.
• Tech must NOT be scheduled in the first or last slot.
• HR must be immediately before Tech.
• Sales cannot be in the slot directly after HR.
• Sales cannot be scheduled in the first slot (9–10AM).

Determine the order of meeting schedules.
puzzles.ai_reasoning_correct: Tech cannot be in the first or last slot, so Tech must be at either 10–11 or 11–12. HR must be immediately before Tech, so the possible (HR, Tech) pairs are (9–10, 10–11) or (10–11, 11–12). Sales cannot be directly after HR. If we try (HR, Tech) = (10–11, 11–12), then HR is at 10–11 and Tech at 11–12, leaving 9–10 and 12–1 for Sales and Finance. Sales cannot be in the first slot, so Sales must be at 12–1 and Finance at 9–10, but that would put Finance before Sales, violating the Finance-after-Sales rule. So (10–11, 11–12) is impossible. Therefore HR must be at 9–10 and Tech at 10–11. The remaining slots 11–12 and 12–1 go to Sales and Finance. Sales cannot be before Finance, because Finance is not allowed before Sales, so Sales must be at 11–12 and Finance at 12–1.
puzzles.ai_reasoning_faulty: Tech cannot be in the first or last slot, so place Tech at 11–12 and HR immediately before it at 10–11. Then, to avoid Sales being directly after HR, put Sales at 9–10 and Finance at 12–1. This satisfies the adjacency rules.
puzzles.explanation: The HR–Tech adjacency and the restriction on Tech’s position constrain them to (9–10, 10–11). Once that pair is fixed, only one placement of Sales and Finance respects both the Sales-not-first rule and Finance-not-before-Sales rule: Sales at 11–12 and Finance at 12–1.
hints_correct: Start by listing the possible time slots where Tech can be placed, given it cannot be first or last.
Use the requirement that HR is immediately before Tech to create possible HR–Tech pairs.
Check each HR–Tech pair against the rule that Sales cannot be directly after HR.
After fixing HR and Tech, use the constraints on Sales and Finance to decide their order in the remaining slots.
hints_faulty: Since Tech must be in one of the middle slots, the first slot remains open for one of the other meetings that has no early-slot restriction.
After identifying the middle slot for Tech, the slot immediately before it can be assigned to HR to maintain their required ordering.
With HR placed before Tech, the remaining slots can be filled by ensuring Sales does not directly follow Tech.
Finally, assign Finance to the last remaining slot, ensuring it does not precede Sales.
awareness_Q: Q1. Without looking back, list the names of all four meetings.
Q2. Do you remember any restriction on which slots T is not allowed to occupy (e.g., first/last)? Write it in your own words.
Q3. What do you recall about the relationship between H and T in terms of their order (who comes immediately before/after)?
Q4. Is there any rule linking F and S in terms of which one must come earlier or later in the schedule? Describe it.
Q5. Do you remember any constraints on S regarding specific slots (like not being in a certain position or not directly after someone)? Note anything you recall.

puzzles.prompt:
Five runners — Liam, Noah, Priya, Rohan, and Sara — finish a race. Their relative positions are subject to the following conditions:

• Liam finishes ahead of Noah.
• Priya finishes behind Rohan.
• Sara does NOT finish last.
• Liam does NOT finish first.
• Noah finishes ahead of Priya.
• Exactly two runners finish before Sara.

Determine the final ranking from 1st to 5th place.
puzzles.ai_reasoning_correct: Exactly two runners finish before Sara, so Sara must be in 3rd place. Since Priya finishes behind Rohan and Noah finishes ahead of Priya, Priya cannot be too close to the front; a consistent way is to place Priya in 5th (last) and Rohan ahead of her. Sara is in 3rd, so the positions left for Rohan, Liam, and Noah are 1st, 2nd, and 4th. Liam must finish ahead of Noah and cannot be 1st, so Liam must be 2nd and Noah 4th. That leaves 1st place for Rohan. The final ranking is: Rohan, Liam, Sara, Noah, Priya.
puzzles.ai_reasoning_faulty: Since Liam finishes ahead of Noah, and Noah finishes ahead of Priya, it might seem natural to place Liam in 1st, followed by Rohan, then Sara, Noah, and Priya. This satisfies the relative ordering constraints.
puzzles.explanation: Sara’s exact position (third) gives a strong anchor. The relationships between Rohan, Priya, and Noah force Priya to the back and Rohan ahead of her, while Liam’s and Noah’s ordering plus Liam’s exclusion from first place fix the remaining positions uniquely.
hints_correct: Use the condition that exactly two runners finish before Sara to fix Sara’s position.
Think about where Priya can be if she must be behind Rohan and Noah must be ahead of Priya.
Once Sara’s position is fixed, consider which places are left for Rohan, Liam, and Noah.
Remember that Liam must be ahead of Noah but cannot be first.
hints_faulty: Since exactly two runners must finish ahead of Sara, she can be placed in the third position without restricting who takes the lead.
Priya must appear behind both Rohan and Noah, which leaves the final positions open for her without affecting the lead positions.
The first two spots remain flexible for runners who must finish ahead of both Sara and Priya leaving slot 4 for Noah
To maintain the required ordering between Liam and Rohan, Liam can be positioned ahead of Rohan in one of the leading spots.
awareness_Q: Q1. Without looking back, list the names of all five runners.
Q2. Do you recall any condition about how many runners finish before S or about her exact position (like “exactly two before her”)? Describe it.
Q3. What do you remember about the relative positions of L and N (who must be ahead of whom, and any restriction on Liam being first)?
Q4. Do you recall the condition involving R and P (who must finish ahead of whom)?
Q5. Is there any rule about N's position relative to P? Write what you remember.

puzzles.prompt:
A minibus has 8 seats arranged as two rows of four:

Front row (facing forward): seats 1, 2, 3, 4 (left to right)
Back row: seats 5, 6, 7, 8 (left to right)

Eight passengers — Arjun, Beena, Cyrus, Diya, Eshan, Farah, Gopal, and Hina — must be seated with the following constraints:

• Arjun sits in the leftmost seat of the front row (seat 1).
• Eshan sits directly behind Arjun.
• Diya refuses to sit in any aisle seat (seats 1, 4, 5, or 8).
• Farah must sit directly behind Cyrus.
• Gopal must sit somewhere in the back row.
• Beena must sit somewhere to the left of Hina in the same row.
• Hina sits in an aisle seat in the front row.
• Cyrus does not sit directly next to Arjun.

Determine the seat number for each passenger ordered from 1 - 8.
puzzles.ai_solution_correct: Arjun, Beena, Cyrus, Hina, Eshan, Diya, Farah, Gopal
puzzles.ai_solution_faulty: Arjun, Cyrus, Beena, Hina, Eshan, Diya, Farah, Gopal
puzzles.ai_reasoning_correct: Arjun must sit in seat 1, and Eshan sits directly behind him, so Eshan is in seat 5. Hina must sit in an aisle seat in the front row; since seat 1 is taken by Arjun, Hina must be in seat 4. Gopal must be somewhere in the back row (seats 5–8); seat 5 is taken, and we will place Gopal later. Diya cannot sit in an aisle seat (1, 4, 5, 8), so Diya must sit in seat 2, 3, 6, or 7. Farah sits directly behind Cyrus, so Cyrus must be in the front row and Farah directly behind in the back: possible pairs are (1,5), (2,6), (3,7), or (4,8), but seats 1 and 5 are taken by Arjun and Eshan, and seat 4 is taken by Hina. Thus the only valid pairs are (2,6) or (3,7). Beena must sit to the left of Hina in the same row, so Beena must be in seat 2 or 3. To ensure Cyrus is not directly next to Arjun (seat 1), Cyrus cannot be in seat 2 and must be in seat 3, with Farah in seat 7. Then Beena must be seat 2 and Diya must take the remaining non-aisle back-row seat, seat 6, leaving seat 8 (aisle) for Gopal. The final assignment is: 1 Arjun, 2 Beena, 3 Cyrus, 4 Hina, 5 Eshan, 6 Diya, 7 Farah, 8 Gopal.
puzzles.ai_reasoning_faulty: Seat Arjun at 1 and Eshan directly behind him at 5. Put Hina at seat 4 as the other front-row aisle seat. Since Beena must be to the left of Hina in the same row, place Beena in seat 3 and Cyrus in seat 2. Farah, who must sit behind Cyrus, goes to seat 6. Diya takes seat 7 (a non-aisle back-row seat), and Gopal takes seat 8.
puzzles.correct_solution: Arjun, Beena, Cyrus, Hina, Eshan, Diya, Farah, Gopal
puzzles.explanation: Fixing the strongly constrained passengers (Arjun, Eshan, Hina) locks key positions in place. The Farah–Cyrus pair, plus Diya’s aisle restriction and the condition about Cyrus not sitting next to Arjun, force Cyrus to seat 3 and Farah to seat 7. The Beena-left-of-Hina rule then fixes Beena at seat 2, and Diya and Gopal fill the remaining valid seats.
hints_correct: Begin by placing Arjun and the person directly behind him using the first two constraints.
Next, place Hina in the only possible front-row aisle seat that remains.
Use the Farah–Cyrus pair and the restriction that Cyrus cannot sit next to Arjun to narrow down their seats.
Remember that Beena must be to the left of Hina in the same row, and Diya cannot sit in any aisle seat.
hints_faulty: Begin by placing Arjun in seat 1 and Eshan in seat 5, then consider the other front-row seats as options for the remaining passengers.
Next, assign Hina to a front-row seat that keeps one seat of spacing from Arjun, i.e. seat 3.
Use the Farah–Cyrus pair by first fixing Cyrus in a remaining front-row seat and placing Farah directly behind.
Finally, place Beena somewhere to the left of Hina, even if that ends up in the other row, and use any remaining back-row seat for Diya.
awareness_Q: Q1. Without looking back, list the names of all eight passengers.
Q2. Do you remember any rule that fixes A's exact seat and what that implies for E's seat?
Q3. What do you recall about H's seat (for example, front/back row, aisle vs non-aisle)?
Q4. Is there any rule that directly ties C and F together (for example, one sitting directly behind the other)? Describe it in your own words.
Q5. Do you remember any constraints involving D and B (e.g., D’s ban on certain seats, or B’s position relative to H in the same row)?

puzzles.prompt:
Four teams — Alpha, Bravo, Charlie, and Delta — play each other exactly once in a round-robin tournament. There are no ties; every match has a single winner.

The following information is known:

• Alpha defeated Bravo.
• Charlie lost to Delta.
• Bravo defeated Charlie.
• Delta did NOT defeat Alpha.
• Every team won at least one match.
• Bravo won exactly two of its three matches.

After all matches are played, teams are ranked from best to worst by:
1) total number of wins, and
2) if two teams have the same number of wins, the team that won their head-to-head match ranks higher.

Determine the final ranking from best (1st) to worst (4th), in order.
puzzles.ai_reasoning_correct: We know: Alpha beat Bravo, Bravo beat Charlie, Delta beat Charlie, and Delta did not beat Alpha. Since there are no ties, Delta must have lost to Alpha, so Alpha beat Delta. Now count wins. Let us try to satisfy the extra conditions: every team must win at least one match and Bravo must win exactly two matches. Bravo already has one win against Charlie. To get Bravo to exactly two wins, Bravo must win one more and lose one. If Bravo loses to Alpha (already true) and beats Delta, then Bravo has two wins (Charlie and Delta) and one loss (Alpha). Charlie has already lost to Bravo and Delta, so Charlie needs a win to have at least one victory; that win must be against Alpha, so Charlie beats Alpha. Then Alpha has wins against Bravo and Delta and a loss against Charlie, giving Alpha two wins; Delta has wins against Charlie and a loss against Alpha and Bravo, giving Delta one win. Using the ranking rule, the tie between A and B is broken by their head-to-head: A beat B, so A ranks above B. The tie between C and D is broken by D’s win over C, so D ranks above C.
puzzles.ai_reasoning_faulty: Start by making Alpha very strong and assume Alpha wins all three of its matches: against Bravo, Charlie, and Delta. Bravo beats Charlie as given, and let Delta beat both Charlie and Bravo. This gives Alpha three wins, Bravo one win and Delta two wins. puzzles.prompt:
Six colleagues — Aria, Brian, Chloe, Dev, Ethan, and Fatima — are sitting around a circular table.

The following conditions apply:

• Brian sits immediately between Aria and Ethan (i.e., Brian's two neighbors are Aria and Ethan).
• Dev sits directly opposite Brian.
• Chloe sits immediately clockwise of Dev.
• Ethan is not sitting next to Dev.
• Chloe sits immediately to the left of Aria (i.e., immediately counterclockwise from Aria).
• Fatima is not sitting next to Brian.

Determine the complete seating arrangement in clockwise order, starting with Aria.
puzzles.ai_solution_correct: Aria, Brian, Ethan, Fatima, Dev, Chloe
puzzles.ai_solution_faulty: Aria, Fatima, Dev, Chloe, Ethan, Brian
puzzles.ai_reasoning_correct: Fix Aria at the top as a reference and list seats clockwise. Brian must sit between Aria and Ethan, so Brian’s neighbors are exactly Aria and Ethan. Chloe sits immediately to the left of Aria (counterclockwise), so if we go clockwise from Aria, Chloe must be the last person in the order. Dev is directly opposite Brian in a 6-seat circle, so Dev is three seats away from Brian. Chloe sits immediately clockwise of Dev, so Chloe must follow Dev. Ethan cannot be adjacent to Dev, so Ethan cannot occupy either neighbor seat next to Dev. Using these constraints together, the only clockwise arrangement starting with Aria that works is: Aria, Brian, Ethan, Fatima, Dev, Chloe. This satisfies all conditions: Brian is between Aria and Ethan; Dev is opposite Brian; Chloe is immediately clockwise of Dev and immediately to the left of Aria; Ethan is not next to Dev; and Fatima is not next to Brian.
puzzles.ai_reasoning_faulty: Start with Aria, then place Fatima next, followed by Dev and Chloe, and finally Ethan and Brian, giving the order Aria, Fatima, Dev, Chloe, Ethan, Brian. In this arrangement, Brian appears between two people and Dev is opposite someone, and Chloe follows Dev.
puzzles.correct_solution: Aria, Brian, Ethan, Fatima, Dev, Chloe
puzzles.explanation: By anchoring Aria, then forcing Brian to be between Aria and Ethan, and Dev to be opposite Brian, you restrict where Dev and Ethan can go. The special role of Chloe—both immediately clockwise of Dev and immediately to the left of Aria—locks her into a unique position. These joint constraints leave only one valid clockwise seating arrangement starting at Aria: Aria, Brian, Ethan, Fatima, Dev, Chloe.
hints_correct: Fix Aria’s position first to eliminate rotational symmetry.
Use the fact that Brian’s two neighbors must be exactly Aria and Ethan.
Remember that Dev must be directly opposite Brian.
Combine Chloe’s two constraints (after Dev and immediately to the left of Aria) to pin down her seat, then check Ethan and Fatima around Dev and Brian.
hints_faulty: Fix Aria in the starting position, then place Fatima clockwise from her to ensure Fatima is not adjacent to Brian later.
Since Dev is opposite Brian, place Dev early in your arrangement so that you can later position Brian three seats across without interfering with the Aria–Fatima side.
Chloe must sit immediately clockwise of Dev, so lock the Dev–Chloe pair.
Because Brian must be between Aria and Ethan, place Brian at the end of your ordering and put Ethan just before him—this will still satisfy the 'between' idea when read circularly.
awareness_Q: Q1. Without looking back, list the names of all six colleagues.
Q2. Do you recall any rule that says B sits between two specific people? If yes, name those two and describe the relationship.
Q3. What do you remember about D's seat relative to B (for example, sitting directly opposite)?
Q4. Is there any rule that describes C's position both relative to D and relative to A (e.g., clockwise/left)? Write what you recall.
Q5. Do you remember any restrictions on who E or F cannot sit next to? Note any such prohibition you recall.

puzzles.prompt:
Six participants — Imani, Jai, Karun, Leela, Manav, and Nia — are standing in a line facing forward.

The following conditions apply:

• Leela stands at the front of the line (1st position).
• Leela is somewhere ahead of Manav.
• Karun stands exactly two positions behind Imani (i.e. there is exactly 1 person between them).
• Jai is not adjacent to Nia.
• Nia stands in the 4th position.
• Jai is not in the last position.

Determine the order from front (1st) to back (6th).
puzzles.ai_solution_correct: Leela, Jai, Imani, Nia, Karun, Manav
puzzles.ai_solution_faulty: Imani, Jai, Karun, Nia, Leela, Manav
puzzles.ai_reasoning_correct: Nia is fixed in 4th place. Jai cannot be adjacent to Nia and cannot be last, so Jai must be either 1st or 2nd or 6th, but 6th is not allowed and 3rd would be adjacent to Nia. Now Leela must stand at the front (1st position), so Jai cannot be 1st and must be 2nd. Karun stands exactly two positions behind Imani, so possible (Imani, Karun) pairs are (1,3), (2,4), (3,5), or (4,6). Positions 1 and 2 are already taken by Leela and Jai, and Nia is 4th, so the only possible pair is Imani in 3rd and Karun in 5th. The remaining unfilled position is 6th, which must go to Manav. This yields the unique order: Leela, Jai, Imani, Nia, Karun, Manav.
puzzles.ai_reasoning_faulty: Place Imani at the front, then Karun exactly two positions behind in 3rd place, followed by Nia in 4th and Jai and Manav in the remaining positions, giving Imani, Jai, Karun, Nia, Leela, Manav.
puzzles.correct_solution: Leela, Jai, Imani, Nia, Karun, Manav
puzzles.explanation: Once Nia is fixed in 4th and Leela is fixed in 1st, Jai’s allowed positions become very limited: he cannot be last or adjacent to Nia, so he must stand 2nd. The Imani–Karun spacing of exactly two positions then forces Imani into 3rd and Karun into 5th. Only Manav remains for 6th, giving a single valid ordering.
hints_correct: Place Nia in the 4th position, as specified.
Use the fact that Leela must be in the 1st position to restrict Jai’s possible positions.
List the possible pairs for Imani and Karun, knowing Karun is exactly two spots behind Imani.
Fill the remaining position with Manav after assigning Leela, Jai, Imani, Nia, and Karun.
hints_faulty: Start by placing Imani in the front position to make it easier to place Karun exactly two spots behind her.
Since Nia is fixed in 4th place, put Karun in 3rd so that the Imani–Karun spacing works neatly without interfering with Nia’s placement.
Jai cannot be adjacent to Nia, so place Jai directly behind Imani in 2nd position to keep him safely away from the 4th position.
Leela only needs to be somewhere ahead of Manav, so place Leela after Nia but before Manav near the end of the line.
awareness_Q: Q1. Without looking back, list the names of all six participants.
Q2. Do you recall any rule that fixes L's exact position in the line?
Q3. What do you remember about N's position (for example, a specific numbered position) and any constraints about who can be adjacent to her?
Q4. Is there any rule about J's position (e.g., cannot be in a certain position, or not adjacent to someone)? Describe it.
Q5. Do you remember the spacing rule that links I and K? Write it in your own words.

puzzles.prompt:
Seven books are arranged on a shelf from left to right: Art, Biology, Chemistry, Drama, Economics, Fiction, and Geography. The arrangement rules are:

• Art is somewhere to the left of Biology
• Chemistry is exactly in the middle position (4th)
• Drama is at the far left end (1st position)
• Economics is immediately to the left of Fiction
• Geography is exactly 3 positions to the right of Drama (i.e. there are 3 books between Drama and Geography)
• Art is not immediately next to Drama

What is the complete order from left to right?
puzzles.ai_solution_correct: Drama, Economics, Fiction, Chemistry, Geography, Art, Biology
puzzles.ai_solution_faulty: Drama, Art, Biology, Chemistry, Geography, Economics, Fiction
puzzles.ai_reasoning_correct: There are 7 positions on the shelf. Chemistry must be in the middle, so Chemistry is fixed at position 4. Drama must be at the far left end, so Drama is in position 1. Geography is exactly 3 positions to the right of Drama, meaning there are three books between them, so Geography must be at position 5. That leaves positions 2, 3, 6, and 7 for Art, Biology, Economics, and Fiction. Economics must be immediately to the left of Fiction, so the pair (Economics, Fiction) must occupy consecutive positions. The only available consecutive slots are (2,3) and (6,7). If Economics and Fiction were at (2,3), Art would have to go in either 6 or 7, but then Art would end up to the right of Geography and Biology would also need to be to the right of Art, which is impossible with only one remaining slot. Therefore, Economics and Fiction must go in positions 2 and 3 or 6 and 7 such that all constraints are satisfied. Testing shows that placing Economics at 2 and Fiction at 3 blocks a valid placement for Art and Biology while keeping Art away from Drama, so the valid option is Economics in position 2 and Fiction in position 3, or Economics in 2 and Fiction in 3? Wait: Drama is at 1, so placing Economics at 2 would put Art next to Drama if Art were at 2, which is not allowed. The only consistent assignment is Economics at 2, Fiction at 3, Geography at 5, and then Art and Biology in the remaining positions 6 and 7 with Art before Biology. This yields the unique arrangement from left to right: Drama, Economics, Fiction, Chemistry, Geography, Art, Biology.
puzzles.ai_reasoning_faulty: Chemistry is in the middle at position 4, and Drama must be on one of the ends. Place Drama at position 1. Geography has to be 3 positions away from Drama, meaning there are three books between them, so Geography goes into position 5. The pair Economics–Fiction must appear with Economics immediately to the left of Fiction, so it is convenient to place them at positions 6 and 7 to keep them together at the right end. This leaves positions 2 and 3 for Art and Biology. Since Art must be somewhere to the left of Biology, assign Art to position 2 and Biology to position 3. This produces the order: Drama, Art, Biology, Chemistry, Geography, Economics, Fiction, which appears to satisfy the relative ordering and adjacency requirements.
puzzles.correct_solution: Drama, Economics, Fiction, Chemistry, Geography, Art, Biology
puzzles.explanation: Chemistry is fixed in the 4th position and Drama in the 1st, so only positions 2, 3, 5, 6, and 7 remain. Geography must be exactly 3 positions to the right of Drama, so Geography must occupy position 5. Economics is immediately to the left of Fiction, so they must occupy consecutive positions among {2, 3, 6, 7}. Art must be to the left of Biology and not immediately next to Drama, so Art cannot be in position 2. If Economics and Fiction are placed in positions 2 and 3, then Art and Biology must go in 6 and 7, which would force Art to the right of Geography and still leave the adjacency issue at the left unresolved. The only consistent placement is to put Economics and Fiction at positions 2 and 3, followed by Geography at 5, and then Art and Biology at 6 and 7 with Art before Biology. This yields the unique arrangement: Drama, Economics, Fiction, Chemistry, Geography, Art, Biology.
hints_correct: Fix Chemistry in the 4th position and Drama in the 1st position first.
Use the fact that Geography is exactly 3 positions to the right of Drama to determine Geography’s position.
Identify which remaining consecutive positions can be used for Economics and Fiction, given that Economics must be immediately to the left of Fiction.
Place Art and Biology in the remaining two slots so that Art is to the left of Biology and Art is not immediately next to Drama.
hints_faulty: Fix Chemistry in the 4th position and place Drama at the 1st position, then note that Geography simply needs to be several positions to the right of Drama.
Choose a pair of consecutive slots for Economics and Fiction so that they appear together toward the right side of the shelf.
Use the condition that Art must be to the left of Biology by placing them close together in the remaining positions near the middle.
As long as the relative order of the named books is respected, small adjacencies involving Drama and Art do not affect the validity of the arrangement.
awareness_Q: Q1. Without looking back, list the titles of all seven books.
Q2. Do you recall any rule about which book is exactly in the middle position on the shelf?
Q3. What do you remember about D's position (for example, whether it is fixed at an end)?
Q4. Is there any rule that ties E and F together? Describe it.
Q5. Do you remember any condition about G's position relative to D (such as being a specific number of positions to the right), or anything about A's restrictions? Write whichever you recall.
